title: AB 1228
content: The State of California enacts the following. The State of California enacts amendments to the Education Code to encourage dissemination of information to foster care agencies by higher education institutions and explore admissions methods for homeless and foster youth. The State of California encourages California Community Colleges to prioritize housing for current and former homeless and foster youth, providing them with housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. The State of California encourages California Community Colleges to prioritize year-round housing for current and former homeless and foster youth, offering it at no extra cost during academic breaks and giving priority to these youth for housing that is available for the most days in a year. Each campus of the California Community Colleges is requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources as needed, regardless of student housing facilities. A "homeless youth" is defined as a student under 25 years of age who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months by a homeless services provider. The Education Code is amended to include provisions for homeless youth, including those verified by a homeless services provider, a TRIO program director, or a financial aid administrator. Former homeless youth retain their status for six years from admission. Each campus of the California State University must prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing, especially during school breaks or year-round occupancy, providing housing at no extra cost. The California State University campuses prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing, offering it at no extra cost during breaks or year-round occupancy. Priority is given to those groups for housing available for the most days in a year. Each California State University campus is requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources as needed, regardless of campus housing availability. A homeless youth is defined as a student under 25 years old who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months. The Education Code is amended to include provisions for homeless youth, former homeless youth, and foster youth to access housing resources at California State University campuses. This includes defining who qualifies as a homeless youth and specifying the duration of their status as a former homeless youth. Each campus of the University of California must prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing, providing them with housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. The University of California prioritizes current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing, providing them with housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. They also give priority to these groups for residence in housing facilities open for occupation year-round. The University of California is requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources as needed during academic terms, including breaks, regardless of student housing availability. A homeless youth is defined as a student under 25 years verified as homeless within the past 24 months by a homeless services provider. The section defines various individuals eligible for housing resources, including a homeless services provider, TRIO program director, and financial aid administrator. It also states that a student verified as a former homeless youth retains that status for six years. The University of California is exempt from this section unless the Regents make it applicable.
